recap_documents.description: Order on Artificial Intelligence entered on 6/8/2023: ORDERED that any submission in a case assigned to Judge Vaden that contains text drafted with the assistance of a generative artificial intelligence program on the basis of natural language prompts, including but not limited to ChatGPT and Google Bard, must be accompanied by: (1) A disclosure notice that identifies the program used and the specific portions of text that have been so drafted; (2) A certification that the use of such program has not resulted in the disclosure of any confidential or business proprietary information to any unauthorized party; and it is further ORDERED that, following the filing of such notice, any party may file with the Court any motion provided for by statute or the Rules of the Court of International Trade seeking any relief the party believes the facts disclosed warrant. SO ORDERED. (SEE ORDER FOR FULL DETAILS) (Chien, Jason) (Entered: 06/08/2023)

caseName: BKNS Management LLC v. Frysta Management LLC

recap_documents.description: MEMO ENDORSEMENT on re: 15 Letter, filed by Frysta Management LLC ENDORSEMENT: Defendant shall file a letter to the Court by May 14, 2025, addressing its citation to Weiss v. Sallie Mae, Inc., 939 F.3d 105, 114 (2d Cir. 2019), in its supplemental brief, Dkt. 12 at 4, and the accompanying quotation that Defendant represented originated from that case. Defendant's letter must identify (1) how this citation came to be included in Defendant's supplemental brief, (2) the process Defendant's counsel took to ensure the accuracy of the citations it provided to the Court, and (3) whether any artificial intelligence program was involved in Defendant's preparation of its supplemental brief. Defendant's letter shall attach affidavits sworn out by Defendant's counsel, Kenneth E. Chase, and any associate or other attorney involved in the preparation of Defendant's supplemental brief, attesting to their knowledge of its preparation. SO ORDERED. (Signed by Judge John P. Cronan on 5/8/2025) (jca) (Entered: 05/08/2025)

Minute Entry for proceedings before Judge John P. Cronan: Oral argument on Plaintiffs motion for summary judgment held on May 7, 2025. Plaintiff may file an optional supplemental reply to Defendants argument that Paragraph 4 of the Note evidences usurious intent; Defendant may file an optional supplemental reply to Plaintiffs argument that the payments made on the Note establish consideration. These supplemental replies may not exceed two pages in length and are due by May 14, 2025. Defendant shall also file a letter to the Court by May 14, 2025, addressing its citation to Weiss v. Sallie Mae, Inc., 939 F.3d 105, 114 (2d Cir. 2019), in its supplemental brief, Dkt. 12 at 4, and the accompanying quotation that Defendant represented originated from that case, including how this citation came to be included in Defendants supplemental brief and whether any artificial intelligence program was involved in Defendants preparation of its supplemental brief. (Court Reporter Martha Martin). (mhe)

caseName: Ryanair DAC v. Booking Holdings Inc.

recap_documents.description: ORAL ORDER: In the letters at Dkt. Nos. 184, 186, and 189, the parties dispute whether the defendants should be compelled to produce the passenger name record ("PNR") codes associated with Ryanair flights purchased using the defendants' platforms. The court will grant the request to compel production of the PNR codes. Those PNR codes may be viewed by two employees selected by the defendants from the list of five employees identified by Ryanair. Those two employees may use the PNR codes only to determine whether and to what extent Ryanair suffered technical losses as a result of the defendants' actions. The PNR codes may not be used by the Ryanair employees for any other purpose, including but not limited to contacting the customers who booked flights through the defendants' platforms, preventing those customers from booking flights in the future, incorporating the data into a machine learning or artificial intelligence algorithm, or accessing the data for any purpose other than determining the amount of technical harm incurred by Ryanair as a result of the defendants' actions. Signed by Judge William C. Bryson on 7/21/2023. (dds) (Entered: 07/21/2023)

REDACTED VERSION of 349 Declaration, re 348 Opening Brief in Support, Declaration of Anthony J. Fuga by Ryanair DAC. (Attachments: # 1 Exhibit 1-8, # 2 Exhibit 9A, # 3 Exhibit 9B, # 4 Exhibit 9C, # 5 Exhibit 9D, # 6 Exhibit 10-17, # 7 Exhibit 18-25, # 8 Exhibit 26-33, # 9 Exhibit 34-42)(Myer, R.) caseName: Flowz Digital LLC v. Flowz Staffing LLC

recap_documents.description: MINUTES OF Scheduling Conference and Motion Hearing held before Judge Stanley Blumenfeld, Jr.: The Court heard argument on Defendants' motion to dismiss 16 and took the matter under consideration. In addition, the Court has concerns about errors in Plaintiff's opposition to the motion to dismiss. For instance, it cites to a case that does not appear to exist and cites to others that do not appear relevant to its arguments. By 5/2/2025, Plaintiff shall disclose, in writing, whether artificial intelligence was used to generate any portion of its opposition, as required by the Court's Civil Standing Order. Court Smart: CS 04/25/2025. (gk) (Entered: 05/01/2025)

See document for further details. (gk) (Entered: 05/05/2025)

caseName: United States v. Anten
firm: AUSA Office of US Attorney, General Crimes Section

recap_documents.description: MINUTES OF FINAL PRETRIAL CONFERENCE; PLAINTIFF'S MOTION IN LIMINE TO ADMIT COMMUNICATIONS AND CONTACTS BETWEEN DEFENDANT AND LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS 43 ; MARK ANTEN'S REQUEST TO SEAL COURTROOM 46 ; DEFENDANT'S MOTION FOR ORDER FOR TO COMPEL PRODUCTION OF MANUALS PERTAINING TO THE FBIS GUARDIAN THREAT ASSESSMENT TOOL 63 held before Judge Wesley L. Hsu as to Defendant Mark William Anten. The final pretrial conference is held. The Court confers with counsel regarding trial related matters as stated on the record. The Court confirms the trial date of June 3, 2024, at 9:30 a.m. The Court GRANTS the United States' unopposed motion to admit certain evidence. (Dkt. 43 ). DEFENDANTS' MOTIONS IN LIMINE. Dkts. 46 and 63 ) Defendant's Request to Seal Courtroom (Dkt. 46 ) is DENIED. Defendant's Motion to Compel Production of Manuals Pertaining to the FBI's Guardian Threat Assessment Tool (Dkt. 63 ) is DENIED, but the Court ordered the United States to produce an FBI 302 related to whether the Guardian tool is artificial intelligence making the threat assessment or whether it is a tool that agents consult when making such assessments. See order for further details. Court Reporter: April Lassiter-Benson. (lom) (Entered: 05/30/2024)
